Description.val:
Ship Communication Automation (52PQ):  With the evolution of afloat networks programs migrating into the Consolidated Afloat Networks and Enterprise Services (CANES) program , the Ship Communications Automation budget line will continue to support Automated Digital Network System (ADNS), Legacy Network Operation Rolling Tide (ORT), Tactical Messaging (formerly Command and Control Official Information eXchange (C2OIX)), Shore Tactical Assured Command and Control (STACC) (formerly Tactical Switching) and Piers / Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA) programs.

Automated Digital Network System (ADNS): ADNS provides cyber hardened warfighting critical, afloat to shore wide area networking. Capabilities include routing, switching, baseband, configuration and monitoring capabilities that interconnect Fleet tactical  and coalition partner enclaves worldwide. ADNS leverages  Commercial Off-the-Shelf/ Government Off-the-Shelf (COTS/GOTS) equipment and network protocols as specified by the joint technical architecture and in support of meeting the ability to connect in a range of contested battlespace environments in support of expanding the Fleets digital competitive advantage. ADNS Increment (INC) I provides ship to shore Internet Protocol (IP) connectivity, separation of enclaves, reuse of unused enclave bandwidth, and ship to tactical shore IP connectivity. ADNS INC II provides capabilities of network to Satellite Communications, Load Balancing, Radio Frequency (RF) restoral, and Quality of Service (QoS) to include application prioritization, Traffic Management, compression and enhancements designed to maximize use of "effective" available bandwidth for surface, shore, and airborne platforms. ADNS INC III combines all Navy Tactical Voice, secure Communications Interoperability Protocol Inter-Working Function, Video, data requirements into a converged IP data stream, and Assured Command and Control (C2) capabilities. This includes Secure Communication Interoperability- Protocol Interworking Function (SCIP-IWF) for secure telephony over IP. In addition, the INC III architecture will incorporate an IPv4/IPv6 dual stack and a Cipher-Text security architecture to align to the Global Information Grid (GIG) in order to mesh Navy tactical surface, subsurface, airborne platforms, and Aegis Ashore sites into a single IP environment with gateway functions to joint and coalition networks.  Technical Insertions (TI) are minor upgrades to existing system hardware and software baseline that are required to maximize Command, Control, Communications, Computer, Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) capability and interface functionality between ADNS and applicable programs.

Legacy Network Cyber Resiliency/Operation Rolling Tide (ORT): ORT is a Navy-wide cyber remediation effort to secure government databases and improve the overall security protocols for Navy computer networks. Specifically, Legacy Network Cyber Resiliency/ORT will fund planned legacy network upgrades and mitigate security vulnerabilities on the highest End of Life (EOL) platforms that are not targeted to be replaced by a CANES system. These upgrades will mitigate known targeted cyber vulnerabilities and include eradication of old Windows Operating Systems, critical EOL firewalls and routers and improved anti-malware solutions. Legacy Network Cyber Resiliency/ORT will improve the networks ability to detect known and unknown vulnerabilities and attacks by upgrading sensor and monitoring technologies and accelerating post-attack containment and recovery. 

Piers / Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA):  Commander Pacific Fleet, Commander United States Naval European Command and Commander United States Naval Central Command have declared pier Information Technology (IT) infrastructure modernization to be a Force Protection matter of urgency.  A fully capable and modern Enterprise pier IT infrastructure allows United States (US) Naval ships, while pier-side at 26 global locations (15 Continental United States (CONUS)/11 Outside Continental United States (OCONUS)), to secure their Radio Frequency (RF) systems for critical maintenance, perform battle force training, while continuing to send and receive operational and intelligence traffic.  This element of the BLII program installs state-of-the-art, Automated Digital Network System compatible IT infrastructure to Navy operated piers worldwide, including public and commercial shipyards and authorized Department of Navy (DON) foreign ports.  EPCA provides expanded Non-Classified Internet Protocol Router Network (NIPRNET)/ Secret Internet Protocol Router Network (SIPRNET) capability to piers to meet Fleet Commander stated requirements in order to maintain situational awareness related to anti-terrorist military operations. Further, it ensures bandwidth requirements are met in order to download critical security patches and updates required for ships to maintain proper Information Assurance (IA) security posture.  While in port, ships are connected by either an Umbilical Cable Assembly (UCA) or a Wireless solution from the skin of the ship to the first Navy Network Operations Center (NOC). Beginning in FY20, Piers/EPCA transitions from LI 8164 Navy/Marine Corps Intranet (NMCI) OCONUS (OCONUS Piers Technical Refresh) to LI 3050 Ship Communications Automation.

Tactical Messaging (formerly Command and Control Official Information eXchange (C2OIX)), provides exchange of Joint Top Secret and below Official Information of high precedence Command and Control (C2) as well as routine organizational record message traffic between ashore sites and afloat platforms.  Tactical Messaging provides sustainment and modernization for messaging systems on over 320 United States Navy (USN), Military Sealift Command (MSC) and United States Coast Guard (USCG) afloat platforms and 4 USN shore communications stations.  The Tactical Messaging modernization effort for afloat platforms replaces the legacy, multi-rack, Naval Modular Automated Communication System (NAVMACS) with a modern, single-rack NAVMACS II system that automates and increases the speed and efficiency of handling organizational message traffic aboard ships and submarines. NAVMACS II leverages the Internet Protocol (IP) networks to send and receive organizational messages during normal operations and interfaces with non-IP serial SATCOM paths to provide resilient C2 traffic during IP outages and Emission Control (EMCON) operations.  C2OIX is the shore component of Tactical Messaging that handles UNCLASSIFIED, SECRET and TOP SECRET message service. C2OIX also provides an integrated Cross Domain Solution (CDS) for over 2,500 shore commands throughout the Navy shore enterprise and over 320 USN, MSC and USCG afloat platforms.  C2OIX is located at the two Naval Computer Telecommunication Area Master Stations (NCTAMS PACIFIC and NCTAMS ATLANTIC) to provide worldwide coverage for shore commands via the terrestrial networks. These suites also provide organizational message data for satellite uplink for afloat units operating in the Atlantic Ocean and Continental United States (CONUS) areas of operation.  Additionally, there are partial C2OIX suites located at two Naval Computer and Telecommunications Station sites (NCTS GUAM and NCTS NAPLES) to provide organizational message data for satellite uplink for units operating in the Indian Ocean and Western Pacific areas of operation.  Tactical Messaging satisfies shore and afloat Navy organizational messaging requirements and implements products that are developed with an open system architecture that allow organizational message exchange between the Navy and other Services and Agencies.

Shore Tactical Assured Command and Control (STACC) is the Navy's Program of Record to consolidate, replace and modernize the ashore wide area network services infrastructure with a cyber-hardened, warfighting resilient hardware, software and enterprise services infrastructure to enable information warfare from and within the tactical domain to expand the Fleets digital competitive advantage. STACC delivers Command, Control, Communications, Computers, and Intelligence (C4I) capabilities that provides the Navy's Command and Control (C2) connection between globally deployed tactical warfighting forces - ships, submarines and aircraft, and key decision makers ashore (Numbered Fleet Commanders and Coalition partners). STACC provides this tactical connectivity through ashore network infrastructure that includes Fleet Network Operation Centers (FLTNOCs), Maritime Operation Centers (MOCs) and DOD Gateways and Teleport sites directly enabling Distributed Maritime Operations worldwide. STACC network provides email, chat, Domain Name System (DNS), and patching applications to afloat platforms in a tactical environment to all deployed warfighting assets across all security classification levels enclaves (UNCLASSIFIED, SECRET, SECRET RELEASABLE (SECREL), VSE, and SCI).

STACC supports Fleet CDRs and Shore C2 users by globally connecting and consolidating common services, enabling resiliency, deploying resilient C2, and proactive network defense through separate and severable "tactical level" network from the "business" network (NMCI, ONE-NET) connecting "afloat" networks such as Integrated Shipboard Network Systems (ISNS)/Consolidated Afloat Networks Enterprise Services (CANES). Unlike NMCI and ONE-NET, STACC is operated and managed by the military allowing for custom network controls, custom COTS/GOTS solutions, increased protection for critical C2 as well as failover capability within a denied environment.

STACC provides and maintains several infrastructure systems essential for the entire Fleet to communicate end-to-end by providing a gateway for the tactical communities by incorporating the latest technologies into an integrated portfolio of products and services that facilitate effective C2 across the force. STACC supports 63 shore sites and over 410 surface and subsurface platforms in both CONUS and OCONUS locations (Maritime Operations Centers (MOC), Commander Task Force (CTF), Navy Computer Telecommunications Area Master Stations (NCTAMS), Naval Computer Telecommunications Stations (NCTS) and Detachments, and Broadcast Control Authorities (BCA)). 

The STACC portfolio includes:
Fleet Network Operation Centers (FLTNOC) and Sensitive Compartmented Information network Operation Centers (SCI NOC)  which provide "tactical" level" networking (IP routing, traffic management, cyber monitoring/protection, storage, and computing) and hosting for multiple critical C4I applications and collaboration tools (Global Command and Control Services - Joint and Maritime (GCCS-J/M), BMD, ISR, Chat, email, etc.) used by Fleet Commanders to provide command and control of deployed forces.

Virtual Secure Enclave (VSE) provides a resilient C2 network (separate and severable SECRET path from the Tactical SIPRNET) designed to survive in a highly contested cyber environment and assure secure C2 communications between our shore Fleet command elements and the deployed warfighters.  VSE is a thin-client architecture residing at the Naval Operation Centers (NOCs). VSE provides secure and resilient C2 network capability for specific Fleet prioritized warfighting commands (e.g., MOC, CTF, etc.) and provides critical C2 applications at the operational level of war in denied environment scenarios. VSE provides secure and resilient application hosting, transport, and authenticated role based access for "tactical" operations.

Combined Enterprise Regional Information Exchange System Maritime (CENTRIXS-M) ashore is a collection of Coalition Classified SECREL networks (separate and severable path) used for coalition (non-US) interoperability in support of military operations. The STACC CENTRIXS-M separates and connects the MOCs, Fleet units, and Expeditionary units to various foreign partner bi-lateral and multilateral coalitions (e.g., NATO). This is a critical element of STACC allowing for collaboration and communication with coalition forces during operations.
  
Transport provides physical end-point connections from ships and submarines to the shore tactical infrastructure; ensuring the network traffic path is transparent to the operators. Transport is critical for providing the secure physical connectivity between shore locations.

Justification.val:
In FY21, Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) continues integration of Assured Command and Control capabilities to meet fleet requirements as well as fielding at Aegis Ashore sites.  In FY21, ADNS funds are for the procurement of (40) Increment (INC) III Afloat units, (51) INC III Afloat Technical Insertion (TI) units, (4) Ashore INC I/INC II units, and (6) Ashore INC III units (to include one Aegis Ashore system), with integration, and associated costs for pre-installation design. In addition, the FY21 ADNS investment will fund installation of (34) INC III Afloat units, (51) INC III Afloat TI units, (4) Ashore INC I/INC II units, and (6) Ashore INC III units.   

In FY21, Piers / Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA) will procure (3) and install (3) EPCA units pier side to address pier Information Technology (IT) infrastructure modernization in support of Force Protection matter of urgency. Funds will support pre-installation design, site surveys, procurement of hardware and software, production support, and installation of Piers IT infrastructure. 

In FY21, Tactical Messaging will procure (10), and install & integrate (10) NAVMACS Afloat units.  Associated costs for pre-installation design to replace old legacy equipment onboard ships and submarines. FY21 increase in average installation cost is due to limited CANES aligned installations.

In FY21, STACC will engineer, procure and integrate (26) STACC Equipment upgrades and perform (27)installations. Upgrades will expand Virtual Secure Enclave (VSE) and CENTRIXS-M infrastructure to support additional Maritime Operation Center (MOC) users, as well as their Commander Task Forces (CTF) in support of the Resilient Command and Control (C2) initiative. FY21 funding will engineer, integrate, procure, and install hardware and software to expand VSE user capacity by 1750 in order to support specific operation plans, adding critical C2 applications for MOC and Commander Task Forces (CTF) users for operation in contested environment situations and provide failover capabilities. In FY21, the capability will be expanded across (10) additional sites in the Pacific and Atlantic regions. 

In FY21, funding for STACC will also engineer, integrate, procure, and install hardware and software for resiliency to: transition legacy serial transport to an IP environment; expand IP services (UNCLASSIFIED, SECRET, CENTRIXS-M, and SCI) to include application hosting services and expanded storage capability; and enhance Network Operations monitoring and management, provide cyber remediation solutions to detect, deter and mitigate network threats and for Assured Command and Control to support terrestrial communications and routing changes.

Name.@footnote: Automated Digital Network System (ADNS): Tech refresh is required to field hardware to address End of Life issues at (4) ADNS Network Operation Centers (NOC): Naval Computer & Telecommunications Station (NCTS) Bahrain, Naval Computer & Telecommunications Area Master Station (NCTAMS) European and Central area of operation (EURCENT), NCTAMS LANT, and NCTAMS PAC sites.
Name.val: 1.1.1) Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) - Ashore - INC I&II

Name.@footnote: Naval Information Warfare Center (NIWC) Pacific (PAC) is the procuring agency for Automated Digital Network Systems (ADNS) Ashore components and leverages multiple contract vehicles with various vendors.

Automated Digital Network System (ADNS): FY19-25 procurement quantities represent minor tech refreshes at 6 sites that include 2 Broadcast Control Authority and 4 NOCs (NCTS Bahrain, NCTAMS EURCENT, NCTAMS LANT, and NCTAMS PAC). Increment (INC) III Ashore units require 3 months integration, assembly, testing and shipping after delivery, prior to installation start. Installs do not begin until 10 months after procurement contract award (7 months production lead time + 3 months integration).
Name.val: 1.1.2) Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) - Ashore - INC III
1.1.3) Legacy Network Cyber Resiliency/Operation Rolling Tide (ORT)

Name.@footnote: FY21 unit cost increase is attributable to procuring Tech Refresh (TR) units whereas FY20 procurements were a mix of TR and Internal Equipment Modifications (IEM). TR units consist of more hardware/components driving the average unit cost increase.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Consolidated Prior Year Requirements - Not Installed
Method:: Installation Name: Installation of Equipment - NAVMACS Afloat
Method:: Installation Name: Installation of Equipment - C2OIX Ashore

ModificationTitle.val: PQ069 Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) - Afloat

Name.@footnote: Design Service Allocation (DSA) costs per unit fluctuates based on the type of platform (submarine vs Multi-purpose Aircraft Carrier, Nuclear -Propulsion (CVN)) and the type of system (Backfit vs new install) and can vary between $15K - $200K.

Title.val: PQ069 Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) - Afloat

Name.@footnote: Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) Increment (INC) III Afloat procurement cost range: $.5M - $1.5M; installation cost range: $.3M - $1.0M. Average unit cost fluctuations for procurement and installation are due to varying system configurations required for surface and submarine platforms. INC III units require 4 months integration, assembly, testing and shipping after delivery, prior to installation start.  Installs do not begin until 12 months after procurement is initiated (1 month administrative lead time + 7 months production lead time + 4 months integration).
Name.val: 1.1.1) Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) - Afloat- INC III - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: FY21: Technical Insertions (TI) will be fielded to include hardware and software baseline updates to Afloat units required to maximize Command, Control, Communications, Computer, Intelligence, and Reconnaissance (C4ISR) capability and interface functionality between Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) and applicable Satellite Communications (SATCOM) systems such as Navy Multi-Band Terminal(NMT), Global Broadcast System(GBS) and Battle Force Tactical Network (BFTN). TI unit cost includes production engineering/integration requirements associated with the initial fielding of TI capability. TI(s) require (1) month administrative lead time and (1) month production lead time.

Name.val: Naval Informaiton Warfare Center (NIWC) -- San Diego, CA (Afloat ADNS Technical Insertion)

Name.@footnote: ADNS: Full Production Contract has 4 possible vendors on Multiple Award Contract (MAC) award:  SERCO, Inc, Science Applciations International Corporation (SAIC), DRS Laurel Technologies, and Leidos. Contract will be used for Increment III production units.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) - Afloat- INC III
[none specified]:: Installation Name: ADNS Tech Insertions

Description.val: Automated Digital Network System (ADNS) is the gateway to the tactical Wide Area Network (WAN) afloat for Internet Protocol (IP) network operations, supporting information dissemination and external connectivity. ADNS allows services and applications to interconnect to the Defense Information Systems Network (DISN) ashore via multiple Radio Frequency (RF) resources and pier connectivity. ADNS provides the only Quality and Class of Service (QoS/CoS) routing for Multi-Service Voice, Video, and Data domains across available Radio Frequency (RF) paths.

ModificationTitle.val: PQ070 Shore Tactical Assured Command and Control (STACC)

Title.val: PQ070 Shore Tactical Assured Command and Control (STACC)

Name.@footnote: Each quantity represents a single STACC Equipment modernization/capability upgrade to a specific site. The cost of each individual modernization effort varies depending on the complexity of modernization required to mitigate cyber security threats, keep pace with increased computing requirements for hosted applications, and support Department of Defense (DoD) directives to remove End of Life (EOL) Windows Operating Systems software as quickly as feasible. Procurements could include refresh of routers, switches, servers, workstations, multi-level thin clients, firewalls across the five security enclaves or be as complex as a complete network refresh.//  The FY 2020 President's Budget request quantities represented the five (5) major shore regions STACC devices are fielded (not the number of STACC Equipment modernization procurements). To better detail requirements, the program has updated quantities to reflect the number of individual STACC Equipment modernization/capability upgrades being procured.  //  There will be over 1,000 different STACC devices fielded at 63 sites across the five major shore regions. Installations can include routers, switches, servers, workstations, multi-level thin clients, firewalls across the five security enclaves.//
The various STACC systems, which make up the network, will be procured and installed in two phases to align with the P-913 MILCON transition schedule.
Name.val: 1.1.3) MILCON P913:Shore Based Enterprise Network Enhancements - NonOrganic

Name.@footnote: Manufacturer for MILCON P-913 STACC equipment. Integration efforts required prior to installation. FY20 award with be on new competively awarded contract.
New competitive STACC engineering services and procurement contract scheduled a February 2020 award.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Consolidated Prior Year Requirements - Not Installed
Method:: Installation Name: PQ070 Shore Tactical Assured Command and Control (STACC)

Description.val:
Shore Tactical Assured Command and Control (STACC) is the Navy's Program of Record to consolidate, replace and modernize the ashore wide area network services infrastructure with a cyber-hardened, warfighting resilient hardware, software and enterprise services infrastructure to enable information warfare from and within the tactical domain to expand the Fleets digital competitive advantage. STACC delivers Command, Control, Communications, Computers, and Intelligence (C4I) capabilities that provides the Navy's Command and Control (C2) connection between globally deployed tactical warfighting forces - ships, submarines and aircraft, and key decision makers ashore (Numbered Fleet Commanders and Coalition partners). STACC provides this tactical connectivity through ashore network infrastructure that includes Fleet Network Operation Centers (FLTNOCs), Maritime Operation Centers (MOCs) and DOD Gateways and Teleport sites directly enabling Distributed Maritime Operations worldwide. STACC network provides email, chat, Domain Name System (DNS), and patching applications to afloat platforms in a tactical environment to all deployed warfighting assets across all security classification levels enclaves (UNCLASSIFIED, SECRET, SECRET RELEASABLE (SECREL), VSE, and SCI).

STACC supports Fleet CDRs and Shore C2 users by globally connecting and consolidating common services, enabling resiliency, deploying resilient C2, and proactive network defense through separate and severable "tactical level" network from the "business" network (NMCI, ONE-NET) connecting "afloat" networks such as Integrated Shipboard Network Systems (ISNS)/Consolidated Afloat Networks Enterprise Services (CANES). Unlike NMCI and ONE-NET, STACC is operated and managed by the military allowing for custom network controls, custom COTS/GOTS solutions, increased protection for critical C2 as well as failover capability within a denied environment.

STACC provides and maintains several infrastructure systems essential for the entire Fleet to communicate end-to-end by providing a gateway for the tactical communities by incorporating the latest technologies into an integrated portfolio of products and services that facilitate effective C2 across the force. STACC supports 63 shore sites and over 410 surface and subsurface platforms in both CONUS and OCONUS locations (Maritime Operations Centers (MOC), Commander Task Force (CTF), Navy Computer Telecommunications Area Master Stations (NCTAMS), Naval Computer Telecommunications Stations (NCTS) and Detachments, and Broadcast Control Authorities (BCA)).

[MILCON P913:Shore Based Enterprise Network Enhancements] Shore Tactical Assured Command and Control (STACC) new suite of systems for the outfitting of the MILCON P-913 NCTAMS LANT new communication facility.  The new NCTAMS LANT building will provide a secure, efficient, sustainable and adaptable communications facility to support all telecommunications requirements within the Atlantic Area of Operations.

ModificationTitle.val: PQ020 Piers / Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA)

Title.val: PQ020 Piers / Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA)

Name.@footnote: In FY21, Piers / Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA) will procure (3) and install (3) EPCA units pier side to address pier Information Technology (IT) infrastructure modernization in support of Force Protection matter of urgency. Funds will support pre-installation design, site surveys, procurement of hardware and software, production support, and installation of Piers IT infrastructure.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: Global Piers - Ashore

Description.val: Piers/ Enterprise Pier Connectivity Architecture (EPCA) quantities represent the number of operational US NAVY pierside locations that will be "touched" in some capacity each fiscal year. Unit cost fluctuations are a direct result of the various sizes of each location. Location size determines the cost and amount of equipment that needs to be procured and installed. Beginning in FY20, Piers/EPCA transitions from LI 8164 Navy/Marine Corps Intranet (NMCI) Outside Continental United States (OCONUS) (OCONUS Piers Technical Refresh) to LI 3050 Ship Communications Automation.
